description: Have each application *produce files containing information* that other applications need to consume. *Integrators take the responsibility of transforming files* into different formats. Produce the files at regular intervals according to the nature of the business
nodes.name: File Transfer

description: Integrate applications by having them *store their data in a single Shared Database*
nodes.name: Shared Database

description: Develop each application as a *large-scale object or component with encapsulated data*. *Provide an interface to allow other applications to interact* with the running application
nodes.name: Remote Procedure Invocation

description: Use Messaging to transfer packets of data *frequently, immediately, reliably, and asynchronously*, using customizable formats
nodes.name: Messaging

description: Connect the applications using a Message Channel, where *one application writes* information to the channel and the *other one reads* that information from the channel
nodes.name: Message Channel

description: Package the information into a Message, *a data record that the messaging system can transmit* through a message channel
nodes.name: Message

description: Use the Pipes and Filters *architectural style* to divide a *larger processing task into a sequence of smaller, independent processing steps* (Filters) that are connected by channels (Pipes)
nodes.name: Pipes and Filters

description: Insert a special filter, a Message Router, which consumes a Message from one Message Channel and republishes it to a *different Message Channel channel depending on a set of conditions*
nodes.name: Message Router

description: Use a special filter, a Message Translator, between other filters or applications to *translate one data format into another*
nodes.name: Message Translator

description: *Connect an application to a messaging channel* using a Message Endpoint, a client of the messaging system that the application can then use *to send or receive messages*
nodes.name: Message Endpoint

description: Send the message on a Point-to-Point Channel, which ensures that *only one receiver will receive* a particular message
nodes.name: Point-to-Point Channel

description: Send the event on a Publish-Subscribe Channel, which delivers a *copy of a particular event to each receiver*
nodes.name: Publish-Subscribe Channel

description: Use a *separate Datatype Channel for each data type*, so that all data on a particular channel is of the same type
nodes.name: Datatype Channel

description: The receiver should move the improper message to an Invalid Message Channel, a special channel *for messages that could not be processed by their receivers*
nodes.name: Invalid Message Channel

description: When a messaging system determines that it *cannot or should not deliver a message*, it may elect to move the message to a Dead Letter Channel
nodes.name: Dead Letter Channel

description: Use Guaranteed Delivery to make messages *persistent* so that they are *not lost* even if the messaging system crashes
nodes.name: Guaranteed Delivery

description: Use a Channel Adapter that can *access the application's API or data* and publish messages on a channel based on this data, and that likewise can receive messages and *invoke functionality inside the application*
nodes.name: Channel Adapter

description: Use a Messaging Bridge, a *connection between messaging systems*, to replicate messages between systems
nodes.name: Messaging Bridge

description: Structure the connecting middleware between these applications as a Message Bus that enables them to *work together using messaging*
nodes.name: Message Bus

description: Use a Command Message to reliably *invoke a procedure in another application*
nodes.name: Command Message

description: Use a Document Message to reliably *transfer a data structure* between applications
nodes.name: Document Message

description: Use an Event Message for reliable, *asynchronous event notification* between applications
nodes.name: Event Message

description: Send a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel
nodes.name: Request-Reply

description: The request message should contain a Return Address that indicates *where to send the reply message*
nodes.name: Return Address

description: Each reply message should contain a Correlation Identifier, a unique identifier that indicates *which request message this reply is for*
nodes.name: Correlation Identifier

description: Whenever a large set of data may need to be *broken into message-size chunks*, send the data as a Message Sequence and mark *each message with sequence identification fields*
nodes.name: Message Sequence

description: Set the Message Expiration to specify a *time limit how long the message is viable*
nodes.name: Message Expiration

description: Design a data format that includes a Format Indicator, so that the message *specifies what format it is using*
nodes.name: Format Indicator

description: Use a Content-Based Router to *route each message to the correct recipient based on message content*
nodes.name: Content-Based Router

description: Use a special kind of Message Router, a Message Filter, to *eliminate undesired messages from a channel* based on a set of criteria
nodes.name: Message Filter

description: Use a Dynamic Router, a Router that can *self-configure based on special configuration messages* from participating destinations
nodes.name: Dynamic Router

description: Define a *channel for each recipient*. Then use a Recipient List to inspect an incoming message, *determine the list of desired recipients*, and forward the message to all channels associated with the recipients in the list
nodes.name: Recipient List

description: Use a Splitter to break out the *composite message into a series of individual messages*, each containing data related to one item
nodes.name: Splitter

description: Use a stateful filter, an Aggregator, to *collect and store individual messages until a complete set of related messages* has been received. Then, the Aggregator publishes a single message distilled from the individual messages
nodes.name: Aggregator

description: Use a stateful filter, a Resequencer, to *collect and re-order messages* so that they can be published to the output channel *in a specified order*
nodes.name: Resequencer

description: Use Composed Message Processor to process a composite message. The Composed Message Processor *splits the message up, routes the sub-messages to the appropriate destinations and re-aggregates the responses back into a single message*
combination of Splitter, Router, and Aggregator
nodes.name: Composed Message Processor

description: Use a Scatter-Gather that *broadcasts* a message *to multiple recipients and re-aggregates the responses back* into a single message
nodes.name: Scatter-Gather

description: Attach a Routing Slip to each message, *specifying the sequence of processing steps*. Wrap *each component with a special message router* that reads the Routing Slip and routes the message to the next component in the list
nodes.name: Routing Slip

description: Use a central processing unit, a Process Manager, to *maintain the state of the sequence and determine the next processing step based on intermediate results*
Business Process Management (separate topic or even pattern language)
nodes.name: Process Manager

description: Use a central Message Broker that can *receive messages from multiple destinations*, determine the correct destination and route the message to the correct channel
nodes.name: Message Broker

description: Use a Envelope Wrapper to *wrap application data* inside an envelope that is compliant with the messaging infrastructure. *Unwrap the message* when it arrives at the destination
nodes.name: Envelope Wrapper

description: Use a specialized transformer, a Content Enricher, to access an external data source in order to *augment a message with missing information*
nodes.name: Content Enricher

description: Use a Content Filter to *remove unimportant data items* from a message leaving only important items
nodes.name: Content Filter

description: Store message data in a *persistent store and pass a Claim Check* to subsequent components. These components can *use the Claim Check to retrieve the stored information*
nodes.name: Claim Check

description: Use a Normalizer to route each message type through a custom Message Translator so that the resulting *messages match a common format*
nodes.name: Normalizer

description: Therefore, design a Canonical Data Model that is *independent from any specific application*. Require each application to produce and consume messages in this common format
nodes.name: Canonical Data Model

description: Use a Messaging Gateway, a class than *wraps messaging-specific method calls* and *exposes domain-specific methods* to the application
nodes.name: Messaging Gateway

description: Create a separate Messaging Mapper that contains the *mapping logic between the messaging infrastructure and the domain objects*. Neither the objects nor the infrastructure have knowledge of the Messaging Mapper's existence
nodes.name: Messaging Mapper

description: Use a Transactional Clientâ€”make the clientâ€™s session with the messaging system transactional so that the *client can specify transaction boundaries*
nodes.name: Transactional Client

description: The application should use a Polling Consumer, one that *explicitly makes a call when it wants to receive a message*
nodes.name: Polling Consumer

description: The application should use an Event-Driven Consumer, one that is *automatically handed messages* as theyâ€™re delivered on the channel
nodes.name: Event-Driven Consumer

description: Create *multiple Competing Consumers on a single channel* so that the consumers can *process multiple messages concurrently*
nodes.name: Competing Consumers

description: Create a Message Dispatcher on a channel that will *consume messages from a channel and distribute them to performers*
nodes.name: Message Dispatcher

description: Make the consumer a Selective Consumer, one that filteres the messages delivered by its channel so that it *only receives the ones that match its criteria*
nodes.name: Selective Consumer

description: Use a Durable Subscriber to make the messaging system *save messages published while the subscriber is disconnected*
nodes.name: Durable Subscriber

description: Design a receiver to be an Idempotent Receiver--one that can safely receive the *same message multiple times*
nodes.name: Idempotent Receiver

description: Design a Service Activator that *connects the messages on the channel to the service being accessed*
nodes.name: Service Activator

description: Use a Control Bus to manage an enterprise integration system. The Control Bus uses the same messaging mechanism used by the application data, but *uses separate channels* to *transmit data that is relevant to the management of components* involved in the message flow
nodes.name: Control Bus

description: Construct a Detour with a *context-based router controlled via the Control Bus*. In one state the router *routes incoming messages through additional steps* while in the other it routes messages directly to the destination channel
nodes.name: Detour

description: Insert a simple Recipient List into the channel that publishes each incoming message to the main channel *and a secondary channel*
nodes.name: Wire Tap

description: Therefore, attach a Message History to the message. The Message History is a *list of all applications that the message passed through since its origination*
nodes.name: Message History

description: Use a Message Store to capture information about each message in a *central location*
nodes.name: Message Store

description: Use a Smart Proxy to store the Return Address supplied by the original requestor and replace it with the address of the Smart Proxy. When the service sends the reply message route it to the original Return Address
nodes.name: Smart Proxy

description: Therefore, use Test Message to assure the health of message processing components
consists of Test Data Generator, Test Message Injector, Test Data Verifier, and Test Message Separator
nodes.name: Test Message

description: Use a Channel Purger to remove unwanted messages from a channel
nodes.name: Channel Purger

description: components are *decoupled* using the messaging pattern
the broker refered in the Loose Coupling Pattern corresponds to the Message Bus in Messaging
Asynchronous communication between partners via messaging
Use a elastic queue, to enable a channel, that can adapt to the load if needed

Pipes-and-filters-based decomposition focuses on for data-centric processing of an application. Each filter provides a certain function that is performed on input data and produces output data after processing. Multiple filters are interconnected with pipes, i.e, through messaging
different cloud provider = different messaging systems

Process-based decomposition focuses on the business processes supported by the application. These processes are comprised out of activities that are executed in a specific order. Functionality is divided into components with respect to the supported business activity
separate data from business logic and presentation
claim check can be used to get rid of the data in business logic
separate state from components via claim check, i.e. extract data from component but leave check to retrive data if needed again.
since claim check has to deal with storing and accessing data consider the data access component
multiple instances of the same processing component. We cannot determine the exact component, so no state should be stored within the component
Processing Component for scaling out. Competing Consumer in a similar way, to split work, i.e. scaling the application / process
the same message can be processed multiple times
